description: From Middle English snid (attested only in the sense of saw and slaughter), from Old English snid, snide (“a cut, incision; cutting implement, saw”), from Proto-West Germanic *snidi; merging with Middle English snede (“a morsel, bite; scythe”), from Old English snǣd (“something cut off, morsel, bit; scythe handle”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland) A cut, a cutting; a slash, a slight wound; a lopping or pruning.

verbs.description: sned (third-person singular simple present sneds, present participle snedding, simple past and past participle snedded)

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, transitive) To lop; lop or chop off.
